archetypes.name: The Hero's Journey
archetypes.description: The common template of stories that involve a hero who goes on an adventure, wins a victory in a decisive crisis, and comes home changed.

archetypes.name: Voyage and Return
archetypes.description: The protagonist travels to a strange world and, after overcoming the threats it poses or learning important lessons, returns with experience.

archetypes.name: Freytag's Pyramid
archetypes.description: A five-part dramatic structure: Exposition, Rising Action, Climax, Falling Action, and Resolution.

archetypes.name: Kishōtenketsu
archetypes.description: A four-act structure common in East Asian narratives. It focuses on a 'twist' or change in perspective rather than a central conflict.

archetypes.name: Overcoming the Monster
archetypes.description: The hero sets out to destroy an evil force which threatens the land. Usually involves a perilous climb and a narrow escape.

archetypes.name: The Trickster's Cycle
archetypes.description: A narrative focused on a clever protagonist who uses wit and deception to solve problems or gain an advantage, often disrupting the status quo.

archetypes.name: The Dilemma Tale
archetypes.description: A narrative structure common in African oral tradition that presents a difficult moral or ethical choice, ending with a question for the audience.

archetypes.name: The Pilgrimage Arc
archetypes.description: A structure where the protagonist undergoes a long journey involving repeated trials that test and build their spiritual or moral character.

archetypes.name: The Virtuous Resistance
archetypes.description: The story of a protagonist who remains steadfast in their values despite intense suffering and external pressure, leading to eventual vindication.

archetypes.name: The Tragic Fate
archetypes.description: A structure common in Old Norse literature where the protagonist's doom is preordained, and the story focuses on their dignified path toward that end.

archetypes.name: The Triple Ordeal
archetypes.description: An escalating narrative structure where the hero must face three major, distinct conflicts, often separated by long periods of time.

archetypes.name: The Moral Fable
archetypes.description: A concise narrative, often featuring animals, that leads to a clear ethical or tactical lesson through the use of wit.

archetypes.name: Exile and Restoration
archetypes.description: A high-status protagonist is unjustly cast out into the wilderness, endures a long period of hardship and loss, and eventually returns to their rightful place.

archetypes.name: The Heroic Sentinel
archetypes.description: A structure featuring a long period of preparation or stasis, followed by a sudden call to action and a journey to protect the realm.

archetypes.name: The Iterative Trial
archetypes.description: The protagonist must complete a series of escalating tasks, usually under the watch of a dangerous supernatural figure, to earn their freedom or a boon.

archetypes.name: The Bringer of Light
archetypes.description: A structure where a trickster figure infiltrates a restricted domain to retrieve a vital element (light, fire, water) for the world's benefit.

archetypes.name: The Deep Transformation
archetypes.description: A narrative of fundamental change where a protagonist descends into a new element or state of being, establishing a new order of nature.

archetypes.name: Rags to Riches
archetypes.description: A protagonist from humble beginnings rises to great heights, suffers a temporary loss or crisis, and finally achieves permanent success.

archetypes.name: The Quest
archetypes.description: A hero and their companions set out to find a specific person or object, overcoming a series of trials until the goal is achieved.

archetypePoints.label: Ordinary World
archetypePoints.prompt: Describe your protagonist's daily life before the adventure begins.

archetypePoints.label: Call to Adventure
archetypePoints.prompt: What event disrupts the hero's world and presents a challenge?

archetypePoints.label: Crossing the Threshold
archetypePoints.prompt: The hero leaves the known world. What is the point of no return?

archetypePoints.label: The Ordeal
archetypePoints.prompt: The greatest challenge. What is the 'lowest point' for your hero?

archetypePoints.label: Return with Elixir
archetypePoints.prompt: How is the hero changed? What do they bring back to their world?

archetypePoints.label: Falling into the Unknown
archetypePoints.prompt: How does the character enter the strange new world?

archetypePoints.label: The Strange World
archetypePoints.prompt: Describe the initial wonders and confusing rules of this new place.

archetypePoints.label: The Great Escape
archetypePoints.prompt: A threat arises. How does the hero find their way back home?

archetypePoints.label: Ki (Introduction)
archetypePoints.prompt: Introduce the characters and their peaceful environment.

archetypePoints.label: Shō (Development)
archetypePoints.prompt: Expand on the world. What are the characters doing day-to-day?

archetypePoints.label: Ten (Twist)
archetypePoints.prompt: Introduce a surprise or a change in perspective unrelated to the main plot.

archetypePoints.label: Ketsu (Conclusion)
archetypePoints.prompt: How does the twist resolve the story in a new, unified way?

archetypePoints.label: The Threat
archetypePoints.prompt: Identify the monster and the danger it poses to the community.

archetypePoints.label: The Ascent
archetypePoints.prompt: The hero approaches the monster's lair. What obstacles do they face?

archetypePoints.label: The Final Battle
archetypePoints.prompt: The hero confronts the monster. This is the peak of the action.

archetypePoints.label: The Ambition
archetypePoints.prompt: What does the trickster want, and what clever plan do they devise?

archetypePoints.label: The Deception
archetypePoints.prompt: Describe the trick played on the unsuspecting target.

archetypePoints.label: The Complication
archetypePoints.prompt: What goes wrong or makes the scheme nearly fail?

archetypePoints.label: The Narrow Escape
archetypePoints.prompt: How does the trickster get away with the prize (or just their life)?

archetypePoints.label: The Scenario
archetypePoints.prompt: Introduce the characters and the conflict that leads to the choice.

archetypePoints.label: The Choice
archetypePoints.prompt: What are the conflicting moral paths or difficult decisions presented?

archetypePoints.label: The Unresolved End
archetypePoints.prompt: Leave the story open. Ask the audience: What should happen next?

archetypePoints.label: Spiritual Call
archetypePoints.prompt: What higher purpose or mission motivates the journey?

archetypePoints.label: Cyclical Trials
archetypePoints.prompt: Describe a recurring challenge that tests the hero's resolve.

archetypePoints.label: Enlightenment
archetypePoints.prompt: The journey reaches its end. What profound truth is attained?

archetypePoints.label: Unbreakable Bond
archetypePoints.prompt: What promise or relationship defines the hero's virtue?

archetypePoints.label: Deepest Ordeal
archetypePoints.prompt: The hero is imprisoned or pressured to betray their values. Describe their suffering.

archetypePoints.label: Justice & Reunion
archetypePoints.prompt: The truth is revealed. How is the hero vindicated?

archetypePoints.label: The Prophecy
archetypePoints.prompt: What knowledge of their inevitable end does the hero possess?

archetypePoints.label: The Choice of Honor
archetypePoints.prompt: Knowing the end is near, what action does the hero take to ensure their legacy?

archetypePoints.label: Final Doom
archetypePoints.prompt: The fate is met. Describe the hero's final stand.

archetypePoints.label: First Great Deed
archetypePoints.prompt: The hero's first major challenge. What proves their worth?

archetypePoints.label: The Shadow Trial
archetypePoints.prompt: A more dangerous, hidden foe emerges. How do they survive?

archetypePoints.label: The Last Battle
archetypePoints.prompt: Decades later, a final threat arrives. What is the hero's ultimate sacrifice?

archetypePoints.label: The Clever Setup
archetypePoints.prompt: Introduce the characters and a tactical problem they must solve.

archetypePoints.label: The Turning Point
archetypePoints.prompt: A clever trick or realization occurs. How does the character outsmart the problem?

archetypePoints.label: The Moral
archetypePoints.prompt: State the lesson learned. How should this change the reader's behavior?

archetypePoints.label: The Fall from Grace
archetypePoints.prompt: What injustice leads the protagonist to lose their home and status?

archetypePoints.label: The Forest Years
archetypePoints.prompt: Describe the long period of wandering and survival in the wilderness.

archetypePoints.label: The Rightful Return
archetypePoints.prompt: The protagonist reclaims their place. How is order finally restored?

archetypePoints.label: The Long Stasis
archetypePoints.prompt: Describe the hero's period of inactivity. Why are they unable or unwilling to act?

archetypePoints.label: The Sudden Strength
archetypePoints.prompt: What supernatural or external force grants the hero the power to move?

archetypePoints.label: The Vigil
archetypePoints.prompt: The hero stands guard at a critical location. Who or what do they defend?

archetypePoints.label: The First Task
archetypePoints.prompt: The introductory test. What simple but crucial instruction is given?

archetypePoints.label: The Midnight Test
archetypePoints.prompt: A more difficult task requiring magical aid. What happens when the world is asleep?

archetypePoints.label: The Final Freedom
archetypePoints.prompt: The hardest task. How does the hero escape the master's power?

archetypePoints.label: The Infiltration
archetypePoints.prompt: How does the trickster sneak into the place where the light is hidden?

archetypePoints.label: The Hidden Treasure
archetypePoints.prompt: Describe the moment the trickster finds the sun, moon, or fire.

archetypePoints.label: The Flight of Light
archetypePoints.prompt: The trickster escapes and releases the light into the world. What is the impact?

archetypePoints.label: The Sacrifice
archetypePoints.prompt: What tragic event or betrayal forces the protagonist into a new realm?

archetypePoints.label: The Deep Change
archetypePoints.prompt: Describe the physical or spiritual transformation as they descend.

archetypePoints.label: The New Order
archetypePoints.prompt: The protagonist now rules a new domain. How does this provide for the world?

archetypePoints.label: Initial Misery
archetypePoints.prompt: Describe the protagonist's humble or oppressed starting condition.

archetypePoints.label: The False Peak
archetypePoints.prompt: The character achieves a sudden, temporary success. What magic or luck makes this happen?

archetypePoints.label: The Midnight Crisis
archetypePoints.prompt: The success is lost or threatened. What is the turning point?

archetypePoints.label: Permanent Rise
archetypePoints.prompt: The character is vindicated. How is their success made permanent and authentic?

archetypePoints.label: The Call & Mission
archetypePoints.prompt: What specific object or person must the hero retrieve, and why?

archetypePoints.label: The First Guardian
archetypePoints.prompt: The first major obstacle blocking the path. How do they overcome it?

archetypePoints.label: The Final Trial
archetypePoints.prompt: The most dangerous test right before the goal. What is sacrificed?

archetypePoints.label: The Retrieval
archetypePoints.prompt: The goal is achieved. Describe the moment the prize is secured.

archetypeExamples.title: The Wonderful Wizard of Oz
archetypeExamples.content: Dorothy lives in a gray, dry Kansas with Aunt Em and Uncle Henry, feeling bored and out of place.

archetypeExamples.title: The Wonderful Wizard of Oz
archetypeExamples.content: A cyclone arrives, lifting the house with Dorothy and Toto inside into the sky.

archetypeExamples.title: The Wonderful Wizard of Oz
archetypeExamples.content: Dorothy is captured by the Wicked Witch of the West and must find a way to destroy her to save her friends.

archetypeExamples.title: Alice in Wonderland
archetypeExamples.content: Alice follows the White Rabbit and falls down a deep rabbit hole into a bizarre world.

archetypeExamples.title: Alice in Wonderland
archetypeExamples.content: The Queen of Hearts demands Alice's execution. Alice realizes the creatures are 'nothing but a pack of cards' and wakes up.

archetypeExamples.title: The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter
archetypeExamples.content: An old bamboo cutter finds a tiny, glowing baby girl inside a bamboo stalk and raises her as Princess Kaguya.

archetypeExamples.title: The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter
archetypeExamples.content: Despite many suitors and great wealth, Kaguya reveals she is not from this world but from the Moon, and her people are coming to take her back.

archetypeExamples.title: Jack and the Beanstalk
archetypeExamples.content: A giant lives at the top of a massive beanstalk and has stolen the wealth of Jack's family.

archetypeExamples.title: Jack and the Beanstalk
archetypeExamples.content: Jack steals the Giant's golden-egg-laying hen and chops down the beanstalk as the Giant chases him, defeating the monster.

archetypeExamples.title: Anansi and the Box of Stories
archetypeExamples.content: Anansi the Spider wants to buy the stories owned by Nyame the Sky God, but the price is high.

archetypeExamples.title: Anansi and the Box of Stories
archetypeExamples.content: Anansi tricks a hornets' nest, a python, and a leopard into capture using only his wits and some simple tools.

archetypeExamples.title: The King's Daughter and the Suitors
archetypeExamples.content: A King offers his daughter's hand to whoever can perform an impossible task. Three suitors succeed in different ways.

archetypeExamples.title: The King's Daughter and the Suitors
archetypeExamples.content: The story ends by asking: 'Which of the three suitors truly deserves the reward?'

archetypeExamples.title: Journey to the West
archetypeExamples.content: The monk Xuanzang is tasked by the Tang Emperor and the Bodhisattva Guanyin to travel to India to retrieve sacred Buddhist scriptures.

archetypeExamples.title: Journey to the West
archetypeExamples.content: Sun Wukong (The Monkey King) and the other disciples protect the monk from 81 tribulations, including demons who want to eat his flesh.

archetypeExamples.title: The Story of Chunhyang
archetypeExamples.content: Chunhyang and Mongryong fall deeply in love and secretly marry, promising eternal fidelity before Mongryong must leave for the capital.

archetypeExamples.title: The Story of Chunhyang
archetypeExamples.content: The corrupt official Byeon demands Chunhyang become his mistress. She refuses and is brutally tortured and imprisoned, facing death for her virtue.

archetypeExamples.title: The Saga of the Volsungs
archetypeExamples.content: Sigurd is born into a line of heroes but is warned by prophecies and his uncle that he is destined for a life of great glory followed by an early, tragic death.

archetypeExamples.title: The Saga of the Volsungs
archetypeExamples.content: Despite knowing the betrayal is coming, Sigurd maintains his honor. He is killed in his bed, fulfilling the 'Wyrd' of the Volsung line.

archetypeExamples.title: Beowulf
archetypeExamples.content: As a young warrior, Beowulf travels to Denmark to defeat the monster Grendel, who has been terrorizing King Hrothgar's hall, Heorot.

archetypeExamples.title: Beowulf
archetypeExamples.content: Fifty years after his first battles, King Beowulf must face a final, massive dragon. He slays the beast but sustains a mortal wound, dying to save his kingdom.

archetypeExamples.title: The Lion and the Hare
archetypeExamples.content: A hungry lion named Bhasuraka is terrorizing the forest. To stop the slaughter, the animals agree to send one animal each day to be his meal.

archetypeExamples.title: The Lion and the Hare
archetypeExamples.content: A tiny hare leads the lion to a deep well, claiming another lion lives inside. The lion jumps in to fight his reflection and drowns. Moral: Wit is superior to brute force.

archetypeExamples.title: The Ramayana
archetypeExamples.content: Prince Rama is about to be crowned King, but his stepmother Kaikeyi demands he be exiled to the Dandaka forest for 14 years so her own son can rule.

archetypeExamples.title: The Ramayana
archetypeExamples.content: After 14 years and defeating the demon king Ravana, Rama returns to Ayodhya. The citizens light lamps to celebrate his return, and he is finally crowned King.

archetypeExamples.title: Ilya Muromets and Nightingale the Robber
archetypeExamples.content: Ilya sits on the stove for thirty-three years, unable to move his hands or feet, until two passing pilgrims heal him and give him heroic strength.

archetypeExamples.title: Ilya Muromets and Nightingale the Robber
archetypeExamples.content: Ilya journeys to Kiev, clearing the road of the monster Nightingale the Robber and standing guard at the city gates as the premier bogatyr (sentinel).

archetypeExamples.title: Vasilisa the Beautiful
archetypeExamples.content: Vasilisa is sent by her cruel stepmother into the woods to fetch light from the hut of the witch Baba Yaga.

archetypeExamples.title: Vasilisa the Beautiful
archetypeExamples.content: Baba Yaga forces Vasilisa to sort massive piles of wheat and poppy seeds by night. Vasilisa succeeds each time with the help of her magical doll.

archetypeExamples.title: Vasilisa the Beautiful
archetypeExamples.content: After Vasilisa answers Baba Yaga's questions about her virtue, the witch gives her a skull lantern and allows her to leave, freeing her from service.

archetypeExamples.title: Raven Steals the Light
archetypeExamples.content: The world is in total darkness because an old man keeps the light in a box. Raven turns himself into a pine needle, is swallowed by the man's daughter, and is born as a baby boy.

archetypeExamples.title: Raven Steals the Light
archetypeExamples.content: As a toddler, Raven cries for the boxes. He opens them one by one, releasing the stars and moon. Finally, he grabs the sun, turns back into a bird, and flies through the smoke hole, placing the sun in the sky.

archetypeExamples.title: The Legend of Sedna
archetypeExamples.content: Sedna is thrown overboard by her father during a storm. When she tries to climb back in, he cuts off her fingers. As she sinks, her fingers become the seals, walruses, and whales.

archetypeExamples.title: The Legend of Sedna
archetypeExamples.content: Sedna becomes the Mother of the Sea, ruling all marine life from her home at the bottom of the ocean. Hunters must now respect her to ensure a successful hunt.

archetypeExamples.title: Cinderella
archetypeExamples.content: Cinderella is forced into servitude by her stepmother and stepsisters, living among the ashes and performing backbreaking chores.

archetypeExamples.title: Cinderella
archetypeExamples.content: With the help of her fairy godmother, she attends the Royal Ball in a magical gown and glass slippers, dancing with the Prince.

archetypeExamples.title: Cinderella
archetypeExamples.content: At midnight, the magic fades. She flees, leaving only a single glass slipper behind, and returns to her life of rags.

archetypeExamples.title: Jason and the Golden Fleece
archetypeExamples.content: Jason is commanded by King Pelias to retrieve the legendary Golden Fleece from the distant land of Colchis to reclaim his throne.

archetypeExamples.title: Jason and the Golden Fleece
archetypeExamples.content: After surviving the Symplegades and completing the impossible tasks set by King Aeetes, Jason retrieves the Fleece from the sleeping dragon.
